results.content: Excellent, outstanding presentation and simplification of some complex concepts and essential core skills.
results.content_html: Excellent, outstanding presentation and simplification of some complex concepts and essential core skills.

results.content:
This was a second tremendous course in R Programming that I have taken from KIrill Eremenko.  I can't state enough about what I have learned in these well-structured and thoroughly instructed courses.
His presentation and explanations as one moves along through the sections is amazing!

I wish that I could say the same for Udemy's lack of appropriately useful responses or follow-up relative to obtaining any Certificates of Completion!

results.content: One of the best course I had on udemy, it really help me understand those techniques from a fundamental level, that's very important for me to further utilize the techniques on my own. Thank you, I appreciate your effort!

results.content: Amazing course, it touches base literally with every component of R. But what I feel is if there has been a mini project at the end combining all the elements taught, it would have been a fun experience.
results.content_html: Amazing course, it touches base literally with every component of R. But what I feel is if there has been a mini project at the end combining all the elements taught, it would have been a fun experience.

results.content:
The good: I did learn a few things, BUT I'm a relative beginner with R, so I should have found this much more challenging. 

Bad: for an 'advanced' course, he took the slow way vs a more 'advanced' way on several lessons, such as importing all the CSV files in S4 manually, versus using lapply, dropping the ending and renaming the list with the file name. 
U3 32: should have mentioned converting time zones. 

S4: the dot operator is an 'advanced' way to refer to a directory? Seriously?
He makes reference to 'going to fast' a lot, when he doesn't. 

Do I have regrets? No. I learned a few things, but I'm pretty new to R. 
Rename this "intermediate" or advanced beginner.

S4: the dot operator is an 'advanced' way to refer to a directory? Seriously?
He makes reference to 'going to fast' a lot, when he doesn't.

Do I have regrets? No. I learned a few things, but I'm pretty new to R.

results.content:
It was amazing learning this advanced course in R, especially getting to understand the apply() family pretty well.
Thank you very much, Sir. I had lots of confusion that you managed to clear all.
So much appreciated, until next time :)

results.content:
First let me say this: the things that are contained within this course are done well. He builds upon the knowledge gained from his beginner's R course in a good manner, and everything was presented in an easy to understand fashion just like his other courses.

But this course had no actual CODING. There were no end-of-section challenges (essentially homework problems) the way his beginner's R course did. If you're already an experienced coder? Okay, you may not need such exercises. But for those of us taking this course as a sequel to his beginner's R programming course, the lack of actual coding is a critical flaw.

For a newer programmer one of the best ways to learn and gain experience is to actually CODE. His beginner's course had challenges at the end of each section where you had to try to take everything you had learned and put it all together into a real, personally coded solution. Such things are very much missing in this course. It's a bare-bones information course with no actual coding.

If this course had optional homework / challenges that we can attempt ourselves along with posted solutions when we run into problems, then this course would be an easy 5/5 (and no, the two short and cursory ones near the end are not enough to count). Without that hands-on experience to help solidify my growing skills, I just can't give this course the high rating it would otherwise deserve.  Anyone coming from Kirill's beginner's course deserves more than what we got here. This course was just a Cliff's Notes reading.
results.content_html:

Okay, you may not need such exercises. But for those of us taking this course as a sequel to his beginner's R programming course, the lack of actual coding is a critical flaw.

For a newer programmer one of the best ways to learn and gain experience is to actually CODE. His beginner's course had challenges at the end of each section where you had to try to take everything you had learned and put it all together into a real, personally coded solution. Such things are very much missing in this course. It's a bare-bones information course with no actual coding.

If this course had optional homework / challenges that we can attempt ourselves along with posted solutions when we run into problems, then this course would be an easy 5/5 (and no, the two short and cursory ones near the end are not enough to count). Without that hands-on experience to help solidify my growing skills, I just can't give this course the high rating it would otherwise deserve. Anyone coming from Kirill's beginner's course deserves more than what we got here. This course was just a Cliff's Notes reading.

results.content: Great course, my 2nd one with Kiril and again I'm very happy. Now, what remains to be seen is how advanced this "advanced" course actually is... :)

results.content: I did the R programming A to Z and once again, the content was greatly presented. The material was taught in an easy to grasp way. I know that the course does not include any practice exercise, but I wish it did, in order to practice those advanced skills

results.content:
The topics covered are truly useful and explained in the brilliant manner, easy to follow and to the point. 

I missed having the Homework part that were present in your other course (R programming A-Z) which I believed really helped to reinforce the knowledge of each section. In my opinion, that was the only thing I missed to give the 5/5

results.content: Very good as usual. I like the approach of learning by doing exercises that are relevant to the real world. The course design is logical and step-by-step so that it needs an incremental effort to put in. What I hope to improve is the update to the current R version as some of the real output is not per the video. In addition, I'd love Kirill to explain a little bit more about the big-picture concept such as why we should use the list in R, as opposed to normal data frame, the way some syntax is organized, for instance - lapply(Weather, "[", 1, 7) - why the "[".

In addition, I'd love Kirill to explain a little bit more about the big-picture concept such as why we should use the list in R, as opposed to normal data frame, the way some syntax is organized, for instance - lapply(Weather, "[", 1, 7) - why the "[".
